question_paper.question_paper_name: IIT M DEGREE AN2 EXAM QPE1 20 Nov 2022
question_paper.question_paper_description: 2022 Nov: IIT M DEGREE AN2 EXAM QPE1

options.option_text: Yes
No

questions.question_text_1: Consider the following statements regarding Design Thinking and Agile:  1. Design Thinking looks at the “why” of a problem while Agile methods focus on the “how” of project delivery. 2. Agile focuses on generating fresh ideas that teams test with a series of user-focused exercises. 3. Design Thinking allows teams to break up the planning and scope of work into smaller units.  Which of the above statements is/are correct?
question_texts: Consider the following statements regarding Design Thinking and Agile:  1. Design Thinking looks at the “why” of a problem while Agile methods focus on the “how” of project delivery. 2. Agile focuses on generating fresh ideas that teams test with a series of user-focused exercises. 3. Design Thinking allows teams to break up the planning and scope of work into smaller units.  Which of the above statements is/are correct?

options.option_text: 1 only
1 and 2 only
2 and 3 only
1, 2 and 3

questions.question_text_1: In the question given below, there are two statements marked as Assertion (A) and Reason (R).  Assertion (A): Design research improves a business’s bottom line through understanding user needs, behaviours and attitudes towards a given product or service – such as a new banking application. Reason (R): Design Research is opinion-based; it seeks to understand what people say about products and services.  Mark your answer:
question_texts: In the question given below, there are two statements marked as Assertion (A) and Reason (R).  Assertion (A): Design research improves a business’s bottom line through understanding user needs, behaviours and attitudes towards a given product or service – such as a new banking application. Reason (R): Design Research is opinion-based; it seeks to understand what people say about products and services.  Mark your answer:

options.option_text: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.
Both A and R are false.

questions.question_text_1: Parking.sg, a mobile app for Singapore parking payments, demonstrates how agencies can adopt an agile, entrepreneurial culture in their way of working and create cutting-edge digital products at a rapid pace. What did the Parking.sg team do to win the official go-ahead for the project?
question_texts: Parking.sg, a mobile app for Singapore parking payments, demonstrates how agencies can adopt an agile, entrepreneurial culture in their way of working and create cutting-edge digital products at a rapid pace. What did the Parking.sg team do to win the official go-ahead for the project?

options.option_text: The team navigated through a maze of approvals and red tape before workingon a solution.
The team brought a concept prototype into stakeholder meetings rather thanexpressing their ideas in abstract plans.
The team proved that it could bypass interdependencies and alignmentneeded for system changes and to mitigate public risks.
The team highlighted the importance of Design Thinking+Agile methodologyto government officials.

questions.question_text_1: With reference to the product and service design, consider the following statements:  1. Designers need to make things that satisfy people’s needs, in terms of function, in terms of being understandable and usable, and in terms of their ability to deliver emotional satisfaction, pride, and delight. 2. Designers must satisfy marketing needs also to ensure that people actually buy and use the product. 3. Designers are not required to possess personal social skills as they counteract the biases of innovators and change the way they engage in the innovation process.  Which of the above statement(s) is/are incorrect?
question_texts: With reference to the product and service design, consider the following statements:  1. Designers need to make things that satisfy people’s needs, in terms of function, in terms of being understandable and usable, and in terms of their ability to deliver emotional satisfaction, pride, and delight. 2. Designers must satisfy marketing needs also to ensure that people actually buy and use the product. 3. Designers are not required to possess personal social skills as they counteract the biases of innovators and change the way they engage in the innovation process.  Which of the above statement(s) is/are incorrect?

options.option_text: 1 and 2 only
2 only
2 and 3 only
3 only

questions.question_text_1: In the aftermath of the Space Shuttle Challenger disaster tragedy in 1986, Richard Feynman participated in a Congressional hearing investigating the cause of the disaster. In what has become a famous anecdote, he sat in front of the congressional panel and demonstrated what happened to the shuttle’s O-rings in the colder-than-normal launch day temperature. Using a glass of water and dropping a clamped O-ring into the glass, he showed how O-rings become brittle and inflexible when exposed to the cold. On the other hand, complex charts produced by engineers in an attempt to warn about the dangers of O-ring exposure to cold temperatures proved to be more confusing than enlightening to those investigating the Challenger disaster. What step in the Design Thinking process can be linked to Richard Feynman’s demonstration?
question_texts: In the aftermath of the Space Shuttle Challenger disaster tragedy in 1986, Richard Feynman participated in a Congressional hearing investigating the cause of the disaster. In what has become a famous anecdote, he sat in front of the congressional panel and demonstrated what happened to the shuttle’s O-rings in the colder-than-normal launch day temperature. Using a glass of water and dropping a clamped O-ring into the glass, he showed how O-rings become brittle and inflexible when exposed to the cold. On the other hand, complex charts produced by engineers in an attempt to warn about the dangers of O-ring exposure to cold temperatures proved to be more confusing than enlightening to those investigating the Challenger disaster. What step in the Design Thinking process can be linked to Richard Feynman’s demonstration?

options.option_text: Conflict of interest
Prototyping to test a hypothesis
User story into before, during and after phase
TRIZ-based ideation

questions.question_text_1: Consider the following case and answer the question:  An online jewellery maker - Sneha started her venture during the lockdown and has been able to scale up her operations over the last few months. She talks to her clients through Instagram and understands their requirements and quotes the price of the personalized jewellery. The customers love this personal touch and added effort - but - doing this leads to a lot of time wastage. If the order-taking becomes streamlined, her USP of being able to provide personal attention to individual orders gets eliminated - giving it the perception of being more mechanical than personal.   To create an ENV model, match the following to their correctly:  1. Order Taking 2. Automated 3. Manual 4. Customisation  A. ELEMENT B. NAME C. VALUE 1 OR 2 D. VALUE 2 OR 1
question_texts: Consider the following case and answer the question:  An online jewellery maker - Sneha started her venture during the lockdown and has been able to scale up her operations over the last few months. She talks to her clients through Instagram and understands their requirements and quotes the price of the personalized jewellery. The customers love this personal touch and added effort - but - doing this leads to a lot of time wastage. If the order-taking becomes streamlined, her USP of being able to provide personal attention to individual orders gets eliminated - giving it the perception of being more mechanical than personal.   To create an ENV model, match the following to their correctly:  1. Order Taking 2. Automated 3. Manual 4. Customisation  A. ELEMENT B. NAME C. VALUE 1 OR 2 D. VALUE 2 OR 1

questions.question_text_1: Consider the following statements:  1. Reduction in the trial & error of innovation. 2. Compromise-free solutions for complex problems. 3. Prediction of technology evolution. 4. Planning and problem avoidance.  Which of the statements given above can be considered as advantages of TRIZ?
question_texts: Consider the following statements:  1. Reduction in the trial & error of innovation. 2. Compromise-free solutions for complex problems. 3. Prediction of technology evolution. 4. Planning and problem avoidance.  Which of the statements given above can be considered as advantages of TRIZ?

options.option_text: 1 and 3 only
2, 3 and 4 only
1, 2 and 3 only

Identify Target Audience B. Curate content and promote a solution C. Address Need and Product Centricity D. Adjust your content and promotion while collecting feedback
question_texts: Match the following drawing parallels between Marketing and Design Thinking   Design Thinking: 1. Empathize 2. Analyze 3. Solve 4. Test  Marketing: A. Identify Target Audience B. Curate content and promote a solution C. Address Need and Product Centricity D. Adjust your content and promotion while collecting feedback

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is/are feature(s) of Human-centered Design (HCD)?[Check all that apply]
question_texts: Which of the following is/are feature(s) of Human-centered Design (HCD)?[Check all that apply]

options.option_text: HCD ensures that the designs match the needs and capabilities of the peoplefor whom they are intended.
HCD avoids specifying the problem as long as possible but instead iteratesupon repeated approximations.
A rigid time, budget, and other constraints of the industry can be a challengeto HCD.
HCD is an area of focus unlike Experience Design or Interaction Design whichare set of procedures.

questions.question_text_1: An online jewellery maker - Sneha started her venture during the lockdown and has been able to scale up her operations over the last few months. She talks to her clients through Instagram and understands their requirements after which,she quotes the price of the personalised jewellery. The customers love this personal touch and added effort - but - doing this leads to a lot of time wastage. If the order taking becomes streamlined, her USP of being able to provide personal attention to individual orders gets eliminated - giving it the perception of being more mechanical than personal - Among the following identify the favourable outcomes upon making the ENV model. [Check all that apply]
question_texts: An online jewellery maker - Sneha started her venture during the lockdown and has been able to scale up her operations over the last few months. She talks to her clients through Instagram and understands their requirements after which,she quotes the price of the personalised jewellery. The customers love this personal touch and added effort - but - doing this leads to a lot of time wastage. If the order taking becomes streamlined, her USP of being able to provide personal attention to individual orders gets eliminated - giving it the perception of being more mechanical than personal - Among the following identify the favourable outcomes upon making the ENV model. [Check all that apply]

options.option_text: Limited Personal Interaction and Flexibility with customers
Smooth and Standardised Order Taking

Time consumption on order taking remains

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statements defines the term ‘User Experience’ correctly?
question_texts: Which of the following statements defines the term ‘User Experience’ correctly?

options.option_text: User experience refers to how a person, the user or a customer, feels aboutinteracting with, or experiencing, a product.
User experience refers to the specific audience a UX designer createssomething for.
It is the creation of a dialogue between a person and a product, system, orservice.
It refers to the ways in which humans interact with computers and designtechnologies that allow humans to interact with computers in novel ways.

questions.question_text_1: Why is it important to call in industry experts while preparing the customer journey map?
question_texts: Why is it important to call in industry experts while preparing the customer journey map?

options.option_text: Experts can help analyse the problem you are trying to solve.
Experts can test the product or service as a user.
Experts can give you a systems-level view of your project area.
Experts can train designers in UX research.

questions.question_text_1: What do we learn from the persona and customer journey map?
question_texts: What do we learn from the persona and customer journey map?

options.option_text: General information about our customers.
New alternative solutions to existing problems.
How to create demand for an innovative product.
What our customers care about.

questions.question_text_1: Why is iterative customer-focused research in the Empathize phase important in Design Thinking?
question_texts: Why is iterative customer-focused research in the Empathize phase important in Design Thinking?

options.option_text: It enables the evaluation of existing products or services.
It provides evidence of what customers want enabling products or services tobe designed to meet these needs.
It can uncover customer needs that have not previously been considered andcan help uncover future customer needs that may not have surfaced.
It helps to generate large amounts of customer data for the research team.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statements accurately describes the Empathize phase of the 4-stage Design Thinking process?
question_texts: Which of the following statements accurately describes the Empathize phase of the 4-stage Design Thinking process?

options.option_text: The design is not just what it looks like and feels like. The design is how itworks.
To know that we know what we know, and to know that we do not know whatwe do not know, that is true knowledge.
Inventing is the resolution of technical contradictions.
If you want to build a product that’s relevant to people, you need to putyourself in their shoes

questions.question_text_1: What are the advantages of ‘silent brainstorming’ in Design thinking?
question_texts: What are the advantages of ‘silent brainstorming’ in Design thinking?

options.option_text: Dampens the voices of normally loud individuals.
Strengthens the voices of experts.
Ensures that individuals gather specific ideas.
Ensures that only a few get the chance to contribute.

questions.question_text_1: What is the function of Inventive Principles in the Solve phase?
question_texts: What is the function of Inventive Principles in the Solve phase?

options.option_text: Help in communicating ideas to your customers
A way of taking the things around us, and turning them into diagrams, ideasand concepts that can be broken down, analyzed and improved upon
Serve as triggers for generating appropriate solutions
This tool is mainly for the engineering division and hence serves no function inthe Design Thinking phases

questions.question_text_1: Which one of the following statements is correct?
question_texts: Which one of the following statements is correct?

options.option_text: TRIZ is regarded as an empirical method because TRIZ involves problem-solving based on contradictions and inventive principles.
TRIZ is regarded as an empirical method because TRIZ reduces time andresources in inventing creative solutions.
TRIZ is regarded as an empirical method because TRIZ is an establishedprocess that has been validated by many researchers.
TRIZ is regarded as an empirical method because TRIZ has been developedthrough organized study and the application of TRIZ involves a step-by-step systematic process.

questions.question_text_1: Bunty and Babli made an app that helps its users streamline Real Estate Purchases. They spent nearly 2 Lakh rupees on promoting it in Malls, Real Estate exhibitions, etc, and got exactly 250 installs. Although as an online promotion - they made an engagement post - which they boosted using an additional Rs. 1 Lakh in the ad manager platform. Within a week - they ended up getting 2000 installs through that post. What is the CPI in this case?
question_texts: Bunty and Babli made an app that helps its users streamline Real Estate Purchases. They spent nearly 2 Lakh rupees on promoting it in Malls, Real Estate exhibitions, etc, and got exactly 250 installs. Although as an online promotion - they made an engagement post - which they boosted using an additional Rs. 1 Lakh in the ad manager platform. Within a week - they ended up getting 2000 installs through that post. What is the CPI in this case?

options.option_text: Rs. 150.00 per install
Rs. 133.33 per install
Rs.50.00 per install
Rs. 44.44 per install

questions.question_text_1: Mr. Bharath Visweswariah while talking about startups and businesses having the first-mover’s advantage mentions a phenomenon called the Network Effect. Which among the following is true for Network Effect? [Check all that apply]
question_texts: Mr. Bharath Visweswariah while talking about startups and businesses having the first-mover’s advantage mentions a phenomenon called the Network Effect. Which among the following is true for Network Effect? [Check all that apply]

options.option_text: Network Effect is a phenomenon whereby new businesses are unable to getnew users because they live in far-fetched areas - away from the company’s distribution network
Network Effect is a phenomenon whereby increased numbers of people orparticipants improve the value of a good or service.
Websites like Facebook and Twitter drive advantage from Network Effect
It is advantageous for Investors to invest in companies taking leverage of thisphenomenon.

questions.question_text_1: Jim Hackett, the former CEO of Ford Motors introduced Design thinking in the company. How has Design Thinking helped Ford Motors in recent days? [Check all that apply]
question_texts: Jim Hackett, the former CEO of Ford Motors introduced Design thinking in the company. How has Design Thinking helped Ford Motors in recent days? [Check all that apply]

Ford could launch Ford Maveric in lesser time and with a lower budget
Improved Ford’s cash flow

props.summary:
### Summary of Core Topics, Concepts, Principles, and Equations

#### Core Topics and Concepts

1. **Design Thinking**
   - **Definition**: A non-linear, iterative process that seeks to understand users, challenge assumptions, redefine problems, and create innovative solutions.
   - **Phases**: Empathize, Define, Ideate, Prototype, Test.
   - **Key Concepts**: User-centered design, empathy, prototyping, iterative testing.

2. **Agile Methodology**
   - **Definition**: A project management and product development approach that emphasizes flexibility, collaboration, and customer satisfaction.
   - **Key Concepts**: Iterative development, sprints, user stories, continuous feedback.

3. **Human-Centered Design (HCD)**
   - **Definition**: A design approach that focuses on the needs, capabilities, and behaviors of people.
   - **Key Concepts**: User research, usability testing, iterative design.

4. **TRIZ (Theory of Inventive Problem Solving)**
   - **Definition**: A systematic approach to innovation and problem-solving based on patterns of invention in the global patent literature.
   - **Key Concepts**: Contradictions, inventive principles, ideality, resources.

5. **User Experience (UX)**
   - **Definition**: The overall experience of a person using a product, especially in terms of how easy or pleasing it is to use.
   - **Key Concepts**: Usability, accessibility, user research, user interface design.

6. **Customer Journey Map**
   - **Definition**: A visual representation of the process a customer goes through to achieve a goal with your company.
   - **Key Concepts**: Touchpoints, emotional highs and lows, user needs, pain points.

7. **Prototyping**
   - **Definition**: Creating a model or sample of a product to test and refine ideas.
   - **Key Concepts**: Low-fidelity prototypes, high-fidelity prototypes, user testing.

8. **Empathy in Design Thinking**
   - **Definition**: Understanding and sharing the feelings of others, crucial for user-centered design.
   - **Key Concepts**: User interviews, observation, empathy maps.

9. **Conflict of Interest with ENV Model**
   - **Definition**: A model used to analyze problems from the perspectives of both the customer and the provider.
   - **Key Concepts**: Element, Name, Value.

10. **Network Effect**
    - **Definition**: A phenomenon where increased numbers of people or participants improve the value of a good or service.
    - **Key Concepts**: User base growth, value addition, social networks.

#### Important Principles

1. **Empathize Phase**: Understanding the user's needs and problems through observation and engagement.
2. **Define Phase**: Clearly articulating the problem you are trying to solve.
3. **Ideate Phase**: Generating a wide range of ideas and potential solutions.
4. **Prototype Phase**: Creating tangible representations of ideas.
5. **Test Phase**: Evaluating prototypes with users to gather feedback and refine solutions.

#### Key Equations (if applicable)

While the questions provided do not explicitly require mathematical equations, understanding the following principles can be beneficial:

1. **Cost Per Install (CPI)**:
   \[
   \text{CPI} = \frac{\text{Total Cost}}{\text{Number of Installs}}
   \]
   Example: If you spend Rs. 1,00,000 on promotion and get 2000 installs, the CPI is:
   \[
   \text{CPI} = \frac{1,00,000}{2000} = 50 \text{ Rs. per install}
   \]

2. **Network Effect Value**:
   \[
   \text{Value} = k \times n^2
   \]
   Where \( k \) is a constant and \( n \) is the number of users.

### Knowledge Graph 

```mermaid
graph TD;
    A[Design Thinking] --> B[Empathize]
    A --> C[Define]
    A --> D[Ideate]
    A --> E[Prototype]
    A --> F[Test]
    B --> G[User Research]
    B --> H[Empathy Maps]
    C --> I[Problem Statement]
    D --> J[Brainstorming]
    D --> K[Silent Brainstorming]
    E --> L[Low-Fidelity Prototypes]
    E --> M[High-Fidelity Prototypes]
    F --> N[User Testing]
    F --> O[Feedback]
    A --> P[Human-Centered Design]
    P --> Q[User Needs]
    P --> R[Usability Testing]
    A --> S[Agile Methodology]
    S --> T[Iterative Development]
    S --> U[User Stories]
    A --> V[TRIZ]
    V --> W[Contradictions]
    V --> X[Inventive Principles]
    A --> Y[User Experience]
    Y --> Z[Usability]
    Y --> AA[Accessibility]
    A --> AB[Customer Journey Map]
    AB --> AC[Touchpoints]
    AB --> AD[Emotional Highs and Lows]
    A --> AE[Conflict of Interest with ENV Model]
    AE --> AF[Element]
    AE --> AG[Name]
    AE --> AH[Value]
    A --> AI[Network Effect]
    AI --> AJ[User Base Growth]
    AI --> AK[Value Addition]
```

This knowledge graph visually maps the relationships between the core topics in Design Thinking, providing a clear and easy-to-understand format.
